name: STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast™
description: The Legacy of Star Wars Dark Forces™ and Star Wars® Jedi Knight lives on in the intense first-person action of Jedi Outcast.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 2000, XP or Vista Processor: Pentium II or Athlon 350 MHz Memory: 64 MB Graphics: 16 MB OpenGL compatible DirectX®: 9.0c Hard Drive: 800 MB Sound: Direct X 8.0a        Multiplayer Requirements: Pentium II or Athlon 400MHz

reviews.review_text: Even after more than ten years, no other game has quite mastered lightsaber combat like this one. There are still active multiplayer servers for Outcast and its successor Academy to this day. If you are a Star Wars fan and haven't played this, change that right now. It's one of the greats.

This may be the best Star Wars FPS / 3rd person ever made. While it is old, it still contains a good mix of puzzles and action. Will never forget the first time playing it. Lightsaber trails on walls, wall running, and storyline all ahead of it's time. A true Star Wars fan game.

I have not played with many Star Wars games throughout my 'gamer career' but what I do remember is the fond memories I have attached to Jedi Outcast. I believe it is supposed to be a sequel to Jedi Knight 1 which is the sequel to Dark Forces 1... all FPS games and very old now and completely missed out by myself.  In any case, Outcast is a blend of FPS and TPS genres. Both perspectives are available throughout the game and they determine the weaponry used to dispose of your enemies. Obviously, weapons such as blasters are for the FPS perspective while wielding your lightsaber is the easiest from a third person perspective.  The game has an excellent story and some recognisable faces appear here and there (strictly following the storyline of the trilogy from the '70s / '80s). Music is, of course, the good-old John Williams-composed score and since they are really good why would we need anything else?  The only issue with the game is that I remember playing it in FPS mode, at first, but once I obtained the lightsaber I finished the rest in TPS mode. I mean, if having a lightsaber is de rigueur in a Star Wars game then why would you want to switch back to the general assortment of weapons? Also, your lightsaber coupled with the many jedi powers available is the best way to play such a game.  The game can be difficult at times but allowing you to follow both paths (i.e. Light and Dark sides) it deserves a second walkthrough. Outcast runs on the Quake 3 engine which, years ago, was quite beautiful but now is somewhat of an obsolete engine. In any case, this is an all-time classic and you are to purchase it especially if you played it already 10 years ago. Collecting classics is always a good pastime!  PS: Widescreen resolutions are unavailable from the game menu - head over to  wsgf.org  to see the solution for the issue.
It's a shame this is no longer canon. I never tire of throwing stormtroopers into other stormtroopers.
doors and elevators can easily kill a jedi master   savage/10
A great star wars jedi experience marred by dodgy platforming, occasionally poor level design and infuriating difficulty spikes.
Probably best Star Wars game

Probably one of the only games i'll ever write a review for but being a diehard Star Wars fan i just have to. So if you are a Star Wars fan searching for a really good game this is the one for you. Sure you'll have to glare over the not as BF1 pretty 2003 graphics but the combat system, story and even the difficulty is well worth it. I for one like a little bit of realism especially when it comes to Star Wars. (pls don't kill me for this but that's why i really like the scene in the phantom menance where Qui-Gon Jin cuts open the door) Which is totally possible in this game with a little bit of autoexec fiddling. Put your lightsaber on cut everthing mode and it finally feels satisfying when you finally slice your way through one of the enemey's shadow troopers or shadow adepts.   So to talk about some of the different aspects of the game.   The prize: If you cant find those 10 Bucks just get it on a sale. I grabbed it for 2€ and got 16 hours of gameplay out of the story alone.   Which also leads me to my next point.    The Gameplay & Difficulty: What really amazed me about this game is that i didnt get bored. New games tend to loose my attention after like 1 1/2 hour but this one just grabbed me and pinned me to my seat ... for hours. Reason for this is that the difficulty is getting procedurely harder as you are getting better and more used to the game. I don't even know how often i reloaded my save after a lousy shadow adept ripped my head of, electrified my corpse and send my remains straight down a cliff. Added to that there is some thinking involved in almost all of the levels aswell which made me actually feel dumb after finally finding an exit or something comparable after 10 minutes of searching and consulting a walkthrough. So if you are looking for a challenge too, this is your game.     Story: Talking about story in the Star Wars franchise which isn't directly related to any of the movies was and is always a dangerous path with Star Wars fans. Take Star Wars: The Force Unleashed, whilst the first game is considered to have a good story but Starkiller being really overpowered, you have the second installment of the game which really lacked in quality causing Disney to pull not only the production but also the canon-plug. What i want to say is that it is really hard to create a good Star Wars story an this game certainly nailed it. You get to meet characters you know and love as it plays some time after the sixth movie. Looking at the plot retroactively you could even think that it is all canon even with the seventh movie already being out. Even though i don't know if it actually is still considered canon.   Now you're probably asking yourself how well does it run?    System Compatibilty: Which is actually pretty interesting. Since the Jedi Knight II is on Steam you threrefore shouldn't have any sytem issues but there a some things that need a manual fixing. The game comes with some wonky unusual resolution settings that noone uses anymore but you i guess we have to cut the game some slack since as i said earlier it came out in 2003. These can be adjusted through a autoexec file which can easily be created and packed with commands. On my machine the game gives my PC a spastic shock when i try to minimize it fullscreen but that could be only my issue.   I hope atleast one of you sat through my whole review and decides to give this amazing game a try after reading through that mess of fandom babbling. Wish you the best time playing and ..... Force ...... you!

A classic, is amongst my favorite games. The game has amazing lightsaber combat, some of the best sword style combat on any platform.  Jedi Outcast has great shooting mechanics as well as easy access Force powers. Being the game came out in 2003, it takes influence from many sources. It contains elements of influence from the matrix, force jump allows you to run up walls, and force speed slows all projectiles around you. The game even has the unreal Flak Cannon (called the flechette gun).   The game has an interesting online community with more than just your standard death match fare. It has a different rule set with players often taking time to duel rather than straight openly murder each other (Though some servers have different rules and contain straight death match)  It's worth taking note you can turn off your lightsaber with the 1 button, often players find the saber turned state as you being hostile.  For the cheap price of 10 bucks this game is worth it, I've spent easily over 400 hours on it. (Not the steam version but when I owned the disc)
Best Game Ever I rate 10/10 pls buy this Speedrunning this game is thebest.

This is one of the most enjoyable games I have ever played, and I just had to bought it on Steam as a tribute. I don't care about graphics, because this game is fun, has a good story and great gameplay; and of course, you get a lightsaber later in the game. It's not just shooting and slashing with lightsaber ( there is a lot of that though ) but you have to think and solve some puzzles to finish the levels. This is probably the best Star Wars game I have ever played. while KOTOR was great too, it wasn't quite enjoyable as this one, this is a faster game with more dynamics.

Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast excels in an area no other game has remotely succeeded: real-time lightsabre combat.  JK2:JO affords players the opportunity to try various lightsabre forms, and perform unique attack in those forms based upon the ways you move your character in the game world. Complete with blocks, combos, parries and lightsabre duels, Outcast is the definitive lightsabre experience in the very long history of Star Wars titles.  Surprisingly, the game is equally good. With a very engaging single player campaign, not to mention riotously fun multiplay, this deserves to be in the collection of every gamer who ever called themselves a Star Wars fan.

Quite honestly the best game to be graced with the Star Wars name. It actually makes you feel like a Jedi. The force powers are comprehensive, believable and fun (Unlike The Force Unleashed which was essentially just a button mashing combo game). The campaign is long and well designed, a must have purchase for any Star Wars fan.
A game I simpl love.  It's a Star Wars classic.  The best saber combat game that has been made so far. Very hard levels. Interesting story.  11/10

Great game- Start off with no, not a lightsaber but a classic E11- Blaster Rifle. The levels are quite puzzling, a challenge for some, breeze for others. Recommend this to Star Wars fans who are up for an adventure. After going through a few puzzling missions, you'll eventually gain force powers and a lightsaber. I'm not going to go any further (spoilers). But the lightsaber battles are great and you will actually use other weapons, so ya don't have to stick with a lightsaber. You can clear enemies in your path with the force (lightning) and throw enemies of edges using force (grip). And you can swap between 1st and 3rd person(s) wielding any weapon.  Great game for Star Wars fans interested in the Expanded Universe.
Awesome fighting mechanics, very challenging campagne and the graphics aren't bad either. Must-Play for every Star Wars fan!
Not only the best starwars game of all time, but one of the greatest first person shooters. This 2002 classic doesen't feel dated in the slightest. BUY IT NOW!

Following on from Dark Forces 2: Jedi Knight, you once again take up the role of Kyle Katarn.  This game is far more modern and doesn't require any tricks to get it running properly, although you will need some ini tweaking to get 1920x1080.  Overall, fun game. Lots of variety, levels, enemies and a good storyline.  Definitely worth a play.  EDIT: Works just fine on Windows 10 Pro x64.

As always old is gold !!! you gotta love the old LucasArts classics !!! and as a star wars fan, this game makes me feel really awesome !! One thing tough, there's really not much freestyle parkour sword + force fighting games that you can play with friends now-a-days...it's really a shame !!! We need games like this one ! i'd definately recommend it to everyone i know and meet in the future ! Game's really awesome,3rd person, it's like Mirror's edge + Star Wars Force Unleashed all together !! really love it ! and you can play with friends 16 peeps in map ! all lightsabering the ♥♥♥♥ out of each other, walking on walls like Matrix's Neo and force lightning your friends asses from time to time ;] amazing game ! definately 10/10 !!!

If you already played Jedi Academy: Jedi Outcast has more challenging AI (for example stormtroopers have ability to make short bursts of fire instead of making 1 inaccurate shot per 5 seconds), there is inventory where you can store medkits, and also you can't choose what force powers you want to develop — the game adds them while you progress the campaign.

It is kinda hard at times but you don't feel like you are cheated, combat is fluent, each weapon has at least two attaxk types, the force powers work great and the lightsaber combat is great.  Checkpoints are slightly annoying though as you restart from the beginning of the level, at least you don't get pushed all the way back to the beginning of the whole game, huh?  Great game. 7/10.

What started off as a fairly strong FPS ended as frustration at poor level design and lightsaber combat that I never felt that I knew how to properly do, let alone excel at. A few cheap instant-death tricks in some of the later maps combined with confusing level navigation. I can't recommend it, despite its reputation.

ok so this is a good game, and I am really only refrencing the storyline of the game itself. The gameplay is outdated and, with a lot of older games, takes a LOT of getting use to.  The AI is that wonderful mix of 'able to dodge your crosshairs while being 100% accuracte'  The game is so old my antrivirus program actually thinks it's a threat to my computer. The graphics will give you a headache with constant exposure. The autosave will only happen one in a blue moon so remember to hammer on that F12 every chance you get.  BUT if you can look past it all, tolerate the crashes, the bugs, the insane drawn out 'puzzle' moments (which comes down to just sheer luck sometimes with dodging rockets) this can be a fun game! Honestly though 'Jedi Academy' did it better. Go watch someone play through this on YouTube, let them endure this game, then buy Jedi Academy and enjoy the game that followed, and improved on the gameplay.

The adventures of everyone’s favorite Kyle Katarn continue in another thrilling Jedi Knight game. And who doesn’t love Kyle anyways? He’s often been referred to as the Chuck Norris of Star Wars. And to people that care about Chuck Norris that probably means something. For me personally, Kyle as seen in these games is more annoying that the Kyle you read about in many of the books.  But I’m not reviewing the latest Fate of the Jedi book, is that series still popular? I’m way behind on my Star Wars novels unfortunately. We’re here to talk about the next in the Jedi Knight series, Star Wars Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast. This time Kyle is back, and what starts with a blue milk run quickly becomes a quest fueled by anger and revenge.  As the Wikipedia blurb said, assuming anybody actually reads those, Jedi Outcast uses the Quake III: Team Area engine. This means we are guaranteed to have a pretty good looking game, ID Tech III was first seen in Quake III Arena back in 1999. It was a beautiful game then, and personally is still a beautiful game. While there will always be things that could be picked at about the engine, and all the games that run on it, it will remain in my book as one of the best looking engines out there.  Jedi Outcast starts off kinda slow, but does pick up its pace once you get your hands on your lightsaber. Which for me took about 4 hours. I’m not going to lie, I had a really tough time with this game for some reason. I’ve played it through in the past, but long enough ago that everything was still new to me. In fact it wasn’t until I got the lightsaber that I realized that I had in fact play Jedi Outcast.  Something about the combat mechanics didn’t agree with me, and while there were some valid complaints. Things like the Imperial Officers take more damage than the Stormtroopers. Stormtroopers that are wearing armor while the Officers simply have their dress uniforms. It would appear that a cotton polyester blend can withstand blaster fire better than the standard issue plastoid armor. Someone should tell Requisitions about this, could save the Empire billions of credits.  You know that line from A New Hope? Where Ben Kenobi says that a lightsaber isn’t as clumsy or random as a blaster. Thereby implying that blasters are both clumsy and random. Well it seems like the developers took that line from the movie and placed it at the core of their combat mechanics. You could fire a blaster six times without moving the mouse and you’ll hit at six different locations. The blasters have a fan effect, one that is made worse if you use the rapid-fire.  While the previous games had a similar fanning of the blaster bolts, they also had an auto-aim that counter balanced it. You didn’t have to be a perfect shot, the blaster would make up for what you lacked in skill. Here they’ve done away with the auto-aim, but left the fanning. Personally, I don’t think Ben was being very literal when he made that statement. Not to the extent that this game makes it seem.  The story I’d call above average, but still falls to some standard video game issues. As with many games there are aspects or parts of the story that feel like they are only there for something to do. Otherwise, were it simply a written story, the segment would have been left out. But I’d can’t blame a game for these moments, as all games tend to have them. The developers want to keep the action up, or to showcase a specific feature or ability in the game, and write a level into the story just for that purpose. Its a common trait, and one that we games have gotten used to. And the better writers and developers can do this, and blend it into the story so well that we tend to not even notice it on the first pass.  Jedi Outcast has the expected character cameos of Luke Skywalker, Mon Mothma, Jan Ors, and Lando Calrissian. And best of all is that Billy Dee Williams actually voiced Lando, giving the character a little more love than the others. Although it was a pretty big coincidence that Kyle should happen to be stranded in the same place where Lando is locked up.  But convenient coincidences aside, the story holds it own with the average of today. As well as the bulk of the gameplay, controls, and puzzles have all aged well. The blasters could use a little work, and perhaps a texture update and you have something that beats a lot of today’s releases. In fact this would be a great game to get a HD remake. And there are probably a couple of other things that I just can’t think of right now, but I guess they’re not that important.

Far and away the pinnacle of the Dark Forces franchise. Perhaps the best single-player Star Wars game ever. Force powers are still a LITTLE bit clunky but not nearly as bad as in JK. Jedi Outcast is a great game with a great story that somehow retains replayability, all while feeling very Star Warsy. It includes none of the gimmicky cameos or iconic locations of Jedi Academy (which really wasn't awful but certainly not a worthy successor) but still hauls you into the Star Wars galaxy and makes you forget you ever left.
Unique and enjoyable lightsaber battles, useful blasters, good game overall.
Jedi with guns.
You can battle with lightsabers so... basically an automatic yes. This game has become one of the classics.

10/10  Buy it now. Superb story line and voice acting, the sabering is mindbuggeringly addictive, the force makes you feel more baddass that 1000 stupidly overpowered Starkillers. Make sure to stick g_saberrealisticcombat 1 on for that added BWAHAHAHA feel. One of the few games that gets melee balance right; both of you are hugely fragile, so it's in the skill of the player. Guns are ok I guess, but if you're like me, you just won't want to use them.  Ace, wonderfully 3 dimensional level design, though sometimes a little short, and textures are looking badly dated in places. Benefits hugely from having played the prequels in story terms.   Lucasarts at their absolute peak. If only it were even longer.

However Im afraid you you lost a mark and thus got a 9/10 as you fumbled to start and took a whole hour and a half to properly grab hold of your lightsaber mr Katarn and we came close to degrading your mark further as you started out fighting like a ♥♥♥♥♥ with the lightsaber. All in All however it was a solid 10 hour performance with your intriguing and obviously pre rehearsed narrative that was a good laugh. One of the Star Wars games to get close to emulating the authentic feel of the movies, Jedi Outcast was also one of the titles that helped change public perception of SW games from cheap cash-ins to heartfelt, fan-made adventures. This is the game in which you get to hang out with Lando Calrissian on the Millennium Falcon. It's also the game where you drive an AT-ST in a jungle and then get taunted by a dark Jedi with a deep voice in a temple while the throne room theme from Return of the Jedi plays.  It's a very 'Star Wars' experience - its attempts to summon nostalgia for the movies succeed much more than in its predecessors Dark Forces and Jedi Knight, or its sequel Jedi Academy. All of those are quality games in their own right, but Jedi Outcast has Lando in it. It feels effortless.  Outcast is far from perfect - its visuals and choppy lightsaber combat have aged poorly even if its blaster-blasting is still fun. Its plot, for all its Star Wars-y-ness and syruppy nostalgia, is pretty silly (a dinosaur is involved). The nineties/noughties obligatory stealth section and needless keycard hunts are a bit of a pain. But I will be god damned if Lando Calrission isn't right there sat next to you with Billy Dee Williams doing the voice and everything.  A fun adventure that gets its tone just right, while the gameplay varies. Recommended easily for fans of the films (Lando cameos btw), but for people who are after a quality shooter/platformer by modern standards, it's just a blue milk run.
Hated it from the start, I guess I'm still stuck in KotR.
Good star wars dark forces 3

this is the first star wars anything i ever experianced and the fact that a game from lucas arts is better then the entire prequel crap fest is water under the bridge. this game is great i never found the graphics a problem ; they are just good enough to look retro but not dated. they are just perfect. the level design is top notch with secrets and large non linear areas like doom. the multiplayer is better then quake ever will be and is the best arena style fps game. the soundtrack is amazing making this feel like a legitimate star wars entry. it is only held back by a frew infuirating puzzles and some FIND THE SWITCH WHILE GETTING SHOT AT FROM EVERYWHERE moments but even those can be fun when you whip out the ol' lightsaber and slice up some fun. the saber combat is amzing fyi. it has 3 modes a lot of cool combo moves you need to learn to pull of and has a stagerring amount of depth. its even reminds me of the combat in dark souls , methodical with quick jabs and positioning being key as opposed to running in and bashing ♥♥♥♥ about. the first levels do a great job introducing the rock solid shooting mechanics and the level desing is top notch. it paces itself super well. it takes hours to finally get a lightsaber and when you do you apreciate the power you weild. and the forces powers a great. choking enemies then dropping them off a cliff will never get old but they feel more accurate then force unleashed. overall best star wars game ever, and 2nd best licensed game every (arkham city takes 1) 10/10 amazing and it runs on just abount anything to boot
good game problem is you should start with lightsaber like jedi acdemy overall great
In this game you play as Kyle Katarn. 10/10.

This game really meant something in my childhood, and now that I own the entire Jedi Knight collection feels as a fulfill of my entire games collection.  They just don't make games like this nowadays...
's pretty good

In the early 2000s, LucasArts published a couple of truly great games; Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds, the only non-Age of Empires game made on the Genie Engine and Jedi Knight II, the closest you can get to being a real jedi knight.  The single player is solid, but if you don't LAN, the game is wasted on you. The multiplayer is diverse, balanced, responsive and a lot more fun than counterstrike or whatever you normally play.  There are two iterations of Jedi Knight II. This is the hard, no frills version with better maps.

If you even remotely enjoy Star Wars and haven't played the Jedi Knight series: Get on it. It's the cream of the crop. The best of the best. The Jedi Knight series is the KOTOR of action games.
ahhhh the feelings and memories!!!

This game was really cool. The story was interesting with a lot of familiar faces, which was exciting, the music is typical Star Wars, meaning it's good, and it's just a lot of fun to feel like an empowered bada$$ Jedi Knight. There are a slew of force powers to use on your enemies including the iconic Force Choke (called Force Grip here), Force Jump, Force Push, Force Pull, and even Force Lightning. Yeah. The lightsaber duels are also quite impressive visually, and employ an interesting mechanic that few other games incorporate. Lightsabers do a LOT of damage. A direct hit is a one-hit kill for most enemies. Some of the more powerful ones take a few more hits. That applies to your character too though. One good hit can be the difference between life and death, especially on the harder difficulties, and it gives the lightsaber combat a very frantic feel. The best thing I can really compare it to is Nidhogg, except 3d and you aren't fighting over territory. That being said the lightsaber duels can also drag on for a long period of time, and it's really, in my opinion, as often tedious as it is fun. This franchise started off as a first person shooter, but over time became more and more focused on lightsaber combat and force powers. If you played dark forces or the original Jedi Knight, you may be dissappointed with the direction this game has taken. The lightsaber and force powers have been significantly upgraded from the original Jedi Knight and completely overshadowed the shooting mechanics. The 1st person shooter mechanics are solid, but completely unnecessary. As a matter of fact it's quite likely you'll spend the whole game using your lightsaber after obtaining it and never use a blaster again. You DO have to reach a certain point in the story to unlock your lightsaber and force powers. Overall, I'd highly recommend this game.

Do I recommend this? Heck yeah! This game has a great story and a cool telling of that story. But I recommend playing the first one first because jumping into the middle of the story is kind of weird. But if you don't, than that's fine too because it does a great job explaining itself.

Had this game many years ago, and i still love it.   ''Star Wars Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast'' has to be one of my favourite game of all times.   The game takes place a long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away. You follow the former Jedi Kyle Katarn, who has abandoned the force. Kyle is after the former Jedi Desann, who betrayed the light side and now follows the dark side. Katarn will use all kinds of weapons throughout the story as he advances through different puzzles and locations. He will eventually learn the way of the force, this includes jumping, pushing, lightning and force grip.   From a scale (-, +. ++, +++)   GOOD +Graphics - (2002) Feels smooth and looks alright.  +++Gameplay - You can disemble and decapitate, do sweet movements or simply blast enemies to death. You choose if you want to play in 1st or 3rd person, gameplay feels really smooth. You will also find yourself solving some puzzles in different planets and environments. Took me 11.4 hours to complete the game on ''Jedi Master'' Difficulty. Can also be modded.  +plot - Interesting. You meet some friendly faces to help you as you progress through the story.   ++Characters - I really like Kyle Katarn as a protagonist. He is like your everyday man, making some clever comments and remains calm even in the trickiest situations. Desann is an interesting antagonist aswell. I wish we'd see more of them in the Star Wars universe.   +++Soundtrack - Great soundtrack. I love hearing the battle soundtrack as I see a sith, ready for a duel.  ++Voice acting - I love the sound of enemies screaming when i chop their limbs off with my lightsaber. Character voices also sounds good, but enemies lack interaction.  +Conrols - Easy to understand.   BAD - I'd like the story to be longer. No DLC's, but mods exist. - It's the same gameplay most of the time. - Game is too easy. - Lack of characters.   Overall rating: 9.5/10

Now you may be asking your self... Do i really want to play this game sense it really makes you think.... yes... yes you do this game does not only have an awesome story but also a big community in guides and some awesome CC that you can use to make the game easier right from the begenning and soooo much more fun... specially the CC for mutilation... Luke accidentally jump on my light saber head first... had to start mission over lololol... oooh nooo storm trooper incoming.... passes right through my light saber im guessin he wont be needing those two arms... or legs... lololol.   Anyways great game, buy both JA and JO, play it JA first then JO. Both Game go for 10$ trust me money well spent, dont trust those people who say wait for it to go in sale... Theirs a way around it to use a saber from the begenning (google) ;P Puzzles: 10: frustrating but rewarding Sound 10: pew pew pew, pshhhhh slicing.... Story 10: me against the whole Empire......... I still outnumber them =)) Play it again 8: Jedi Academy takes the cake sorry lol

Disclaimer :  I got this game for almost nothing in some Star Wars Humble Bundle that i bought for other games a few year back, that's why i'm considering i got the game for free (probably for less than 0.25€)  I hadn't played this game for more than 10 years... A friend lent me the game back then, but i never finished it. When i noticed it in my Steam library this week-end so i decided to give it another try.   The game is a blend of FPS and third person lightsaber combat. Weapons feel responsive, sound great, and carry the nostalgia of these early-2000s Star Wars games. The graphics are not bad, they aged well in my opinion and i'm genuinely still amazed by the marks left by lightsabers on walls.  Now for the cons :  * First it's clearly not worth 10€ in 2016.  * Some game mechanics are NOT introduced, i discovered that i could use objects, after being stuck for half an hour in the only part of the game that really require using them (The nightvision goggles in the hangar level). Moreover, i only discovered during the final level that i could heal myself using a force power. (Explaining why the last levels were so hard, since medipacs were not provided anymore as i was supposed to use the force...)   * Talking about levels, they seem well designed at first glance, but they are a labyrinthic mess. Prepare to run around levels you just cleared for hours before finding out an utterly hidden ventilation grid on the ceiling of a random room that will lead to the next part of it. This happens in every level and i wasn't prepared for that. I still can't believe some levels of this game made it through QA and play-testing, as half of them require you to perform jumps that would have been considered as glitch/skips in any decently-designed game.  TL;DR : This is overall a good experience, but kinda frustrating if you are used to modern games that have corrected the youthful errors of this one over a decade.  6.5/10
